awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Three-dimensional structure of Arctic tides and near-inertial oscillations, and their role in changing the Arctic Ocean and ice pack
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arctic Ocean is undergoing rapid change. Implications are significant for strategic and tactical military planning; regional, and perhaps global, climate; northern ecosystems and cultures; and economic interests. Climate models qualitatively agree that these changes will persist. Projections of when specific benchmarks, such as an ice-free summer Arctic Ocean, will be reached vary by several decades. Reducing uncertainty in Arctic change projections is an important task. This project identifies tides and near-inertial (NI) waves, with periods of approximately 12 hours, as the major components of Arctic ocean velocity fields, mixing rates and ice dynamics that are not presently represented in global coupled climate models. The project will provide the Arctic community with a database of time-dependent tidal and NI energy in select current meter records. Also, it will provide a carefully-validated, high-resolution, fully-forced Arctic coupled ocean/sea-ice model (OIM) for quantifying the effects of high-frequency (HF) processes on seasonal and longer-term variability of the Arctic Ocean and its ice pack. The project will contribute to STEM workforce development through support for the training of a post-doctoral associate and a graduate student, and through support for two early-career scientists. K-12 outreach will be enabled through in-person and webinar programs at schools in AK, TX, WA and OR. A public-friendly video with visualization of model results will be prepared and distributed to schools and other communities including coastal Alaskan villages, and highlighted on the project website.

Motivated by observations of strong HF ocean currents and ice drift velocities that are very sensitive to
changes in sea-ice state, sparse measurements of HF time series of ocean mixing and ice deformation,
and coarse-grid models with parameterized tide forcing, this project tests the following hypothesis: "Energetic, HF processes, including tides and wind-generated NI waves, are critical contributors to the seasonal cycle and longer-term trends of the Arctic's 3-D hydrography and circulation, sea-ice characteristics, and exchanges of heat, freshwater and momentum between the atmosphere, ocean and sea-ice." The program's specific goals are to map the time-dependent distribution of HF energy in the ocean and ice throughout the Arctic; assess the role of HF processes in the Arctic ice and upper ocean; develop understanding of the HF processes coupling the sea ice, ocean, and atmosphere; and quantify the effect of HF processes on seasonal cycles and longer-term trends. Taking advantage of rapidly growing databases for ocean and sea-ice velocities, and improvements in resolution and physical realism of OIMs, it integrates analyses of tidal and NI signals in select Arctic ocean moorings and sea-ice drift data, validation of a high resolution (~2 km x 106 vertical levels) pan-Arctic OIM with full atmospheric and tidal forcing, and comparison of a suite of model simulations with different forcing to identify dominant HF processes. Simulations with simplified forcing (e.g., removing tides and low-pass filtering the winds to reduce NI forcing) will identify key factors involved in HF influence on ocean and sea-ice state on seasonal and longer time scales. Focus areas include the effect of HF processes on ice formation and dispersion of river freshwater and heat fluxes in shelf seas, on mixing of Atlantic- and Pacific-sourced waters along the Arctic continental slopes, on feedbacks between ocean and sea-ice HF processes, and on the seasonal cycle of atmospheric heat exchange with the ocean and sea ice.

por.por_cntn:
Motivation and Summary

In this project, we investigated the hypothesis that high-frequency (periods of several hours to about a day) processes such as tides and near-inertial waves (ocean oscillations driven by winds and the rotation of the earth) play an important role in how the Arctic Ocean and its sea ice change on longer time scales associated with climate variability. If these processes are important, computer models of the Arctic as a complete system including the ocean, sea ice and atmosphere must be improved.  We used measurements of the ocean and sea ice, along with several computer models, to show how tides and near-inertial waves (ocean oscillations associated with winds and the rotation of the earth) vary around the Arctic and change the distribution of heat and salt in the upper part of the Arctic Ocean. This project was a collaboration between four US institutions: Earth and Space Research (OR & WA), University of Alaska Fairbanks (AK), University of Texas at Austin (TX), and Atmospheric and Environmental Research (MA). In addition, we coordinated our studies with researchers in the UK, Norway and Germany. Our results are documented in 8 peer-reviewed publications, and we have created several data and modeling products that are openly accessible through the Arctic Data Center.

Scientific Outcomes

The principal effect of tides on the ocean and ice comes from the currents, not tide heights. We found that tidal currents are only strong in a few regions, particularly in the eastern Arctic where warm water from the Atlantic Ocean first flows into the Arctic north of Norway. However, tide-driven changes that occur in this region are then distributed around the entire Arctic by the large-scale circulation. Important tide-driven processes include: mixing as tidal currents flow across the seabed; tidal-period "internal" waves that can then radiate away from their generation regions over sloping seabeds into the deep ocean; and generation of large, high-frequency waves (periods of a few minutes) that can cause intense mixing and can be seen from space with satellite radar systems.  In modeling studies, we found that tides change the local ocean structure but are also sensitive to that structure and the mean ocean currents associated with it. This mutual dependence implies an interesting and potentially important feedback: as the Arctic changes in response to large-scale forcing changes including those related to human activities, the effect of tides can also vary. That is, we cannot rely on modern tide models to tell us what tidal currents might be like in the future.

Tides also change the sea ice concentration: by doing this, they affect how fast sea ice forms in autumn and winter and melts in spring and summer. Tidal changes can affect ship navigation in these regions; this was already noticed in 1893 by Fridtjof Nansen when his ship, "Fram", was parked in the pack ice north of Russia. We also investigated the role of tides in melting at the bottom of one of Greenland's remaining ice shelves, and found that tides played a major role in the variability of this melting. In turn, these patterns of melting influence where freshwater from the Greenland Ice Sheet will enter the surrounding seas and the North Atlantic Ocean.

We also looked at how other ocean variability associated with eddies and "continental shelf waves" (both with time scales of several days) could transfer energy from where these features are generated to other areas of the Arctic. Eddies generated near Svalbard can travel thousands of kilometers eastward to effect mixing and sea ice changes there, and can also carry nutrients. The continental shelf waves are a mechanism for wind forcing in one region to drive currents in remote locations.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of our project include the following. (1) The creation of new, high-resolution tide models of the Arctic was our first major application of NSF XSEDE High Performance Computing resources, and becoming familiar with using these is a major development for ESR personnel. (2) The project PIs supervised a PhD student at UAF, who is now a postdoc in Norway with one of our international project partners. (3) Numerous other researchers, including graduate students, use our tide models and ESR personnel routinely assist these users with model choices and code setup. (4) Our models and code are publicly available through the Arctic Data Center, GitHub, and other sites. (5) Until the start of the Covid-19 epidemic, ESR personnel routinely carried out K-12 outreach activities in the Seattle area.
